column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: The Code of Conduct and Integrity, together with the Equal Opportunity and Appropriate Behaviour Policy and Workplace Resolutions Statement, outlines the expectations of employees, contractors and suppliers who work within our business. These expectations are explained through inductions, training and leadership development programs.

column7: Fortescue's Human Rights Policy applies to all Fortescue employees, directors, suppliers, contractors, consultants and other business partners. During FY23, Fortescue did not identify any confirmed instances of modern slavery in our supply chain.

column6: Operations and suppliers ar significant risk for incidents of forced or compulsory labor
column7: Fortescue's Human Rights Policy applies to all Fortescue employees, directors, suppliers, contractors, consultants and other business partners. During FY23, Fortescue did not identify any confirmed instances of modern slavery in our supply chain.

column6: Security personnel trained in human rights policies or procedures
column13: Training on human rights and modern slavery is mandatory for all employees. During FY23, Fortescue continued the rollout of the online human rights training, while an updated, advanced training module on Human Rights and Modern Slavery continues to be delivered, face to face, to individuals working in higher-risk areas.

column6: Incidents of violations involving rights of indigenous peoples
column13: Fortescue is party to seven major native title agreements with native title groups in the Pilbara region, three underpinned by registered Indigenous Land Use Agreements (ILUA). Through the seven major native title agreements and dozens of First Nations heritage agreements, Fortescue has worked closely and transparently to manage over 6,500 heritage places.
column20: Native title agreements, Indigenous Land Use Agreements, rights of indigenous peoples

Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Billion Opportunities program forms a critical element of the approach to ensuring economic opportunity and growth for the Traditional Custodians of the company's operating regions. The program is complemented by practical initiatives that provide First Nations businesses with the tools to build value and sustainability, creating employment and development opportunities.
column20: Billion opportunities, First Nation, development opportunities

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Fortescue signed a major agreement with the Nyamal traditional custodian group to provide mining equipment for our Iron Bridge Magnetite Project. Contracts like this support the growth of First Nations businesses, enabling them to build capability, which in turn provides ongoing economic benefits to communities.
column20: Partnership contract, First Nation business, economic benefit

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Since 2017, Fortescue has partnered with ANZ to offer a funding program that allows eligible First Nations businesses to access finance at a competitive rate. Fortescue acts as a guarantor, which removes the need for the First Nations business to provide security.
column20: Capital funding, partnership, First Nations businesses

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Fortescue operates flights that link the Pilbara operations with major northern communities in Western Australia and the Northern Territory. The flights allow the employees to access work sites while living in regional communities with their families, supporting local economies.
column20: Regional flights, regional communities, local communities' economic growth

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Fortescue supports a regional FIFO workforce for the Pilbara iron ore operations, supporting employees based in Port Hedland, Broome, Fitzroy Crossing, Kununurra and Karratha. Over 95 per cent of the total procurement spend, including FFI and excluding Fortescue WAE, was with Australian businesses and entities, 68 per cent was within Western Australia, and 1.8 per cent was with local Pilbara suppliers.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Community benefit sharing involves sharing the financial and other benefits of Fortescue's projects with local communities. These benefits are measures that go beyond compensation and impact mitigation to enhance the social and economic outcomes for the local community
column20: Benefits sharing, local communities, economic enhancement

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: .Community investment is used to build stakeholder relationships and demonstrate the commitment to supporting thriving communities. Fortescue prioritises community needs, partnering with credible local organisations to build capacity and deliver sustainable outcomes.

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: Local content is often linked closely with community investment in education, capacity building and training, with both workstreams actively developing local capability and economic advantages through project participation. As a global company, Fortescue seeks to consistently drive local value creation for communities by focusing on research and development, green energy education, training for employment, and opportunities for small and medium enterprises.

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
column13: In managing project impacts, Fortescue followed the environmental and social principles and standards, including the IFC Performance Standards and the Green Hydrogen Standard, where applicable, through effective impact assessment and management practices throughout the entire project lifecycle. Fortescue also used a collaborative approach, ensuring community stakeholders were engaged.
